summary: Quid Pro Quo
title: Quid Pro Quo
body:
read it on the AO3 at http://bit.ly/2IT4DZp

by olly_octopus

“Angel,” Crowley purrs sweetly, voice dripping with temptation and all the sins of Hell that would make Gabriel violently throw up at the golden gates. “Angel, sweetheart, have I ever told you that your eyes are filled with all the stars in the heavens?”
“Of course they are,” replies Aziraphale crossly. “I’m a celestial being, just below God herself. Where else would you expect to find the stars?”

***

Or, Crowley discovers the one angel he wants to flirt with also happens to be the one being in the universe that doesn’t really understand it. Fluff and awkwardness ensues.

Words: 2033, Chapters: 1/1, Language: English

  • Fandoms: Good Omens (TV), Good Omens - Neil Gaiman & Terry Pratchett
  • Rating: Not Rated
  • Warnings: Creator Chose Not To Use Archive Warnings
  • Categories: M/M
  • Characters: Aziraphale, Crowley, Gabriel I suppose
  • Relationships: Aziraphale/Crowley (Good Omens)

summary: I have jumped on the bandwagon and have bought the Good Omens book. The book purely because I don’t have an Amazon nor do I want...
body:
I have jumped on the bandwagon and have bought the Good Omens book. The book purely because I don’t have an Amazon nor do I want one, and I was at a bookstore today.

I have read very little, but enjoy immensely what I have. Mostly the humor.


(on the opposite side of the spectrum, I bought theodd1sout’s book as well.)

summary: Can we just quickly talk about how, when Aziraphale gave his sword away, Crowley decided to protect him from that moment on. And...
body:
Can we just quickly talk about how, when Aziraphale gave his sword away, Crowley decided to protect him from that moment on. And then in this moment, despite having his sword again, he still proclaims that he still needs Crowley!? Thank you for attending my Ted Talk. ❤️💛

@emblue-sparks

(AO3)

summary: listen though in the bandstand scene when Crowley curses God, Aziraphale’s answer is a heartfelt-seeming “May you be forgiven.”...
body:
listen though in the bandstand scene when Crowley curses God, Aziraphale’s answer is a heartfelt-seeming “May you be forgiven.” and maybe that’s a knee-jerk reaction; he’s an angel, after all, and God is love, God is forgiveness. but then Crowley reacts to that.

“I won’t be forgiven. Not ever. That’s part of a demon’s job description. Unforgivable, that’s what I am.”

and at that moment, Aziraphale realizes something… Crowley truly believes that. and beyond that, so do the other angels, and so do the other demons. humans can repent and be forgiven, humans can redeem themselves, but what about demons? what about Crowley, specifically? Crowley, who is horrified by the idea of hurting children. Crowley, whose worst ‘deeds of the day’ tend to amount to pranks. Crowley, who has always been there, rescuing Zira at need, making him laugh, supporting him. Crowley, who has done good deeds, as part of the Arrangement, while Aziraphale himself has done evil. is Zira less unforgivable, then, just because he never fell, while still occasionally literally doing the work of Hell on earth? how can Crowley be unforgivable?

how long do you think Aziraphale thought about that after they parted from each other in anger (on a note which was very like a break up), not sure if or when he’d ever see Crowley again, or if he’d have a chance to say anything else to Crowley after that? how long do you think he regretted everything which had ever made Crowley feel that he’s unforgivable – unloveable, it’s not too far a stretch to say – and regretted that he himself never did enough to make Crowley feel otherwise?

it’s no surprise, then, that one of the very first things he says to Crowley the next time they speak is an instant and unreserved “I forgive you.” yes, on the surface it’s in the context of a response to Crowley saying “for someone so clever you can be very stupid” but I really don’t think that’s what Aziraphale is actually responding to.

because it’s not, this time, the platitude of “may you be forgiven,” that passive-voiced mealy little sentiment. may someone forgive you. someone, the divine, whoever. no. this time, it’s active, it’s direct, it’s first person. I forgive you.

he may never have said the “L word” but he didn’t need to. he did something which means just as much, between an angel and a demon. he gave his full and uncompromised forgiveness to a being which deserves it, and then some.

reblog.comment:
listen though in the bandstand scene when Crowley curses God, Aziraphale’s answer is a heartfelt-seeming “May you be forgiven.” and maybe that’s a knee-jerk reaction; he’s an angel, after all, and God is love, God is forgiveness. but then Crowley reacts to that.

“I won’t be forgiven. Not ever. That’s part of a demon’s job description. Unforgivable, that’s what I am.”

and at that moment, Aziraphale realizes something… Crowley truly believes that. and beyond that, so do the other angels, and so do the other demons. humans can repent and be forgiven, humans can redeem themselves, but what about demons? what about Crowley, specifically? Crowley, who is horrified by the idea of hurting children. Crowley, whose worst ‘deeds of the day’ tend to amount to pranks. Crowley, who has always been there, rescuing Zira at need, making him laugh, supporting him. Crowley, who has done good deeds, as part of the Arrangement, while Aziraphale himself has done evil. is Zira less unforgivable, then, just because he never fell, while still occasionally literally doing the work of Hell on earth? how can Crowley be unforgivable?

he may never have said the “L word” but he didn’t need to. he did something which means just as much, between an angel and a demon. he gave his full and uncompromised forgiveness to a being which deserves it, and then some.

summary: “or i’ll never talk to you again” sounds like a threat, and in context aziraphale sounds like he means it as a threat (and it’s...
body:
“or i’ll never talk to you again” sounds like a threat, and in context aziraphale sounds like he means it as a threat (and it’s a good one)

but it’s also, like, a statement of fact, because if satan comes they’re all fucked and aziraphale simply won’t be able to talk to crowley again, because they’ll both be dead

summary:
omg,,,, i really said fuck it and made a Good Omens OC huh 😳😳😳
ok so this is just for fun and although I've watched the series...
body:
omg,,,, i really said fuck it and made a Good Omens OC huh 😳😳😳

ok so this is just for fun and although I’ve watched the series completely I’ve just started the book + Christian theology isn’t exactly my strong point sO excuse any mistakes/contradictions ✌️😔

This angelic fella is Ramiel (who I read is the angel responsible for guiding souls into Heaven) and he’s basically in charge of Purgatory, which for his lil storyline is quite literally a waiting room between our mortal plain. I mean,,,, literally a waiting room. Heaven hasn’t updated it in a while so it has the exact aura of an insurance company reception room in 2007. It attempts to have some earthly pleasures but fails tremendously. A mixture of elevator music, Mmmbop and S Club 7 drones eternally from an unseen stereo, attempting. fruitlessly to offer comfort and solace to the human attendees. It’s an awful kitschy limbo. Each person passing through is given a waiting ticket and, based off my lil diagram in the ref, you’re gonna be in there for a WHILE. Attempting to bust through to Heaven before your time will basically just let you loose into an endless Labyrinth of these things:

Ramiel himself is fuckin trying he. iS FUCKENG. TRYING OKAY!!!! He’s trying so hard to be cheerful and helpful when in fact he doesn’t even have a clue what’s gonna happen or how long the wait’s gonna be. All he can do is smile and go ‘make sure you have your number!’

In my mind he’s played by Jack McBrayer to complete the holy trinity of my favourite actors, also including Jon Hamm and Michael Sheen. ✌️😳
